children: A 58-year-old woman is evaluated for vaginal burning and dyspareunia.
Findings of the external genitalia and vaginal introitus (
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has vulvovaginal atrophy that is associated with the genitourinary syndrome of menopause. Classic vulvar and vaginal findings include shiny, smooth, and dry vaginal epithelium with loss of rugae. Inflammatory changes may include erythema and petechiae. Patients with vulvovaginal atrophy may also have sparse pubic hair and introital narrowing. Patients typically note vaginal burning or irritation; sexual symptoms, such as dyspareunia or sexual dysfunction; or urinary symptoms, such as dysuria or recurrent urinary infections. These symptoms are the result of estrogen deficiency.
